response.answer_text: Even the Greks were hardly literate, only 5% in Athens, less elswhere. Based on more trustable Latin sources - From IV century BC, gradually Greek dialect was introduced (via nobility) [E. Borza #1 authority]. The status of the ancient Macedon language is still debated. The kings always declared as Macedons (Alexnder the Great is made up recent substitution).  The Macedon nobility was multilingual - required to control wide areas.Hellenism was popular, due to the convenience of the copied Phoencicial script & easy way to pass knowledge/directions/religion.Not yet known what the Macedons language was like, so the Romans were closer to the truth. Of course, the Romans had superior administration to control over 1200 Greek city-states + the huge Macedon Kingdom for much longer. Their evidence is more reliable, not excluded to be biased, as the Greek sources were (Diogen had hard time to find honest Greeks). The conclusion is that I now know that I know nothing.
